------=_NextPart_000_017F_01C88817.C3194E20
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Peter,
 
Yes, I believe this is a powerful idea.  In effect the perturbations need
not be a collision, although that analogy works, but can be an output from
other networks.
 
There are many things one can do with an intersection of graph
thermodynamics (including, Fruchterman-Reingold, Kamada-Kawai, Eades, etc)
force directed graph layout and artificial neural networks. Why limit the
interaction in 2D, or 3D space?
 
This is a technique I use to model a system network graph in a context
(another system network graph).  The input, output and bias nodes of the
system under examination are the interface nodes between the system and its
context.  I'm still experimenting with this methodology - in between trying
to earn a living.
 
Ken


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
petar_chervenski
Sent: Monday, March 17, 2008 9:57 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Spatial & connective CPPNs for Alife domains



Hi again :) 

I am developing an Alife pet project evolving 2D mass-spring based 
creatures. The fitness function can't exactly be defined, since they 
can be evolved towards some tasks like "go there" or something. I 
want to briefly describe the details behind it. 

The same network is used for both the body and the nervous system of 
the creature. First the body is built by a spatial CPPN and converted 
to a mass-spring model. There are several tissues (the CPPN outputs 
tissue type instead of level of expression). One type of tissue is a 
sensor tissue, which excites upon collision. Another type of tissue 
is a muscle tissue, which contracts the springs when excited. Like a 
regular bilogical muscle. 

The key point is, that after the spatial CPPN builds the body, the 
same CPPN is then used for HyperNEAT (additional outputs, though), to 
evolve the connectivity of the neural network controlling the body. 
Inputs are located on sensor tissue only. Outputs are located on 
muscle tissue. Hidden nodes are located on the remaining tissue. This 
is essentially evolving both the substrate and the connectivity of 
the network, but in a meaningful way, because of the geometry and the 
simulated 2D physics space. 

The simulation is like this - when the sensor tissue is excited by 
some collision, this also plugs 1.0 into the associated HyperNEAT's 
network's inputs. When the outputs activation level exceeds some 
treshold, the associated springs on the muscle tissue are contracted. 

I believe that using the same network for both pusposes (spatial and 
connective) is better than using different networks. Do you think 
this in general is a good idea? 

Peter



 


------=_NextPart_000_017F_01C88817.C3194E20
